edge: Approved the film after being fascinated by the idea of exploring the 'unfinished-ness' of the case and impressed by director Meghna Gulzar after seeing her work in Dus Kahaniyaan.
Collaborated with the Talwar couple to create a film based on the Noida double murder case, which they had researched for nearly two years.
The film presents three perspectives on the case: the police investigation, and two different CBI investigations.
Central figures in the police investigation of the Noida double murder case.
Subjects of the first CBI investigation after they were accused of killing their daughter and domestic help.
Subjects of a second CBI investigation following allegations that the first investigation was inadequate.
The names of individuals and organisations were changed in the film to avoid legal issues related to Aarushi Talwar's case.
The names of individuals and organisations were changed in the film to avoid legal issues related to Aarushi Talwar's case, which involved Rajesh Talwar as well.
The names of individuals and organisations were changed in the film to avoid legal issues related to Aarushi Talwar's case, which involved Nupur Talwar as well.
Lawyer and politician Ram Jethmalani said that the trial depicted in the film was inaccurate, which contradicts the accuracy of the depicted events.
The first draft of the screenplay was written in a year.
Aarushi's aunt, Vandana Talwar (who began a campaign to prove the parents' innocence), provided some material to Bhardwaj.
The title Talvar was initially registered with Pritish Nandy Communications (PNC), but was purchased by Bhardwaj.
Initially a film's co-producer, Pritish Nandy Communications (PNC) withdrew from the project.
Meghna said that Talvar alludes to the sword that is held in the hand of the lady of justice.
Meghna said that if the film serves its purpose, it would begin a debate about re-examining the case.

According to an interview, Meghna found filming the murder scenes in Talvar to be the most challenging aspect of the production.
